snippet: Iraqi Kurds are selling oil and natural gas directly to Turkey, upsetting Baghdad and Washington, which fear a broader independence for Kurds in Iraq’s north.
abstract: Iraqi Kurds are selling oil and natural gas directly to Turkey, infuriating the United States and central government in Baghdad; fear is that oil independence could lead Kurds in Iraq's north to declare a broad independence and fracture the nation; year-and-a-half-long diplomatic drive by US to stop flow has so far failed, reflecting Washington's diminished influence in region.

byline.original: By TIM ARANGO and CLIFFORD KRAUSS
byline.contributor: Tim Arango reported from Istanbul, and Clifford Krauss from Houston. Duraid Adnan contributed reporting from Baghdad, and Sebnem Arsu from Istanbul.

lead_paragraph: Iraqi Kurds are selling oil and natural gas directly to Turkey, upsetting Baghdad and Washington, which fear a broader independence for Kurds in Iraq’s north.

headline.main: Kurds’ Oil Deals With Turkey Raise Fears of Fissures in Iraq
headline.print_headline: Kurds’ Oil Deals With Turkey Raise Fears of Fissures in Iraq
